Issues.Title: Optionally keeping previous Component non-destroyed while routing to a new Component
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core, router

### Description

Optionally, I want to keep my previous page as active when I want to open other pages. So, when I close this new page, I could go back to my previous page with everything left as it was.

Yeah, I know that I can save somewhere previous component's state, and re-init with that state data when I come back to that page, but it's not a good solution, here's why:

1. I cannot always save each state of a components, there might be some pure template (html/css/js, css animations, etc.) related things which I cannot save and re-init with.

2. Even if I can save each state of a component, it would be huge overhead to always check every time whether I have added this some new state into my state saving mechanism.

3. There might be really heavy to render components with lot's of initial calculation, so when I needed to switch to a different route for a second (maybe, select something from my list in a different route) and come back, I don't want it to re-render everything.
Instead, I want to keep my prevoius page as it is (like as if I just hide it) when I want to open some different, and want to come back in a second. And, maybe come back with some data even (but this is another feature..)

Some real-world scenarios:

While I am filling a hude Form, I need to fill select input, when I couldn't find proper item from a select input dropdown, I would want to add this item into that entity which should be done in a totally different route, so if I could open that route as a dialog* (page dialog - this is a name of my requesting feature), I wouldn't need to save everything on this page into some service, I would just add my new item and continue filling my form in my previous page.

### Proposed solution

As a solution, I think, I need some directive to use with routeLink, like: routerLinkAsDialog maybe. So, when I set this to true, I want Angular not to destroy my current component, and open new route component on the top of my current component. When I close that new page (with selecting something, or by saving something) I want to come to my last active page.

It is going to look like having layers of pages which are alive, so, when I close one, the last one going to open, etc.


### Alternatives considered

Alternattive considerations would be the ability to access data of my active pages. However, it is not that critical feature to have.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Optionally keeping previous Component non-destroyed while routing to a new Component" (#55207)

Issues.Title: Effect usage causes undesirable changes in behavior to existing components due to timing
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

This may not be a bug, but I'm looking to give feedback on signals, and some functionality that I'm seeing missing.

When trying to prototype changing some components from `@Input` to signals, I'm seeing a gap in functionality with regards to `effect` usage and the timing of `effect` callback execution.

In my prototyping, I have been trying to achieve signal based components and directives with no Angular lifecycle methods (`ngOnChanges`, `ngOnInit`, etc.).

The difficulty I am having is due to the timing of when `effect` callback methods are executed. In the places I am having issues is when I need to run code when inputs change. For structural directives, akin to `*ngIf`, I need to call `createEmbeddedView` when one or more `input` values change. For components, I may need to invoke methods on services and therefore there is no local caller of the value (like the template using an input and therefore `computed` could be used for affected code as well).

In these case, `effect` does work, but the problem is that child components will have been initialized and executed **before** the parent effect runs. To be able to go fully signal-based, I'm trying avoid using `ngOnInit` or `ngOnChanges`

One work-around seems to be to use `computed` and invoke the computed method during `ngOnInit` as an alternative to using `effect` to ensure the code is run before children components are initialized.

Originally I posted this as a question at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/78213307/passing-an-angular-signal-value-from-a-component-input-into-a-service

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-hjmcgz?file=src%2Fmain.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

In this stack blitz application, if you open the developer tools console, you will see that the child components will get no value for `b` and `d`. `b` is a property on a provider that is set by the top level component in an `effect`. `d` is the same but uses `toObservable` instead of `effect`. In both of these use cases, the child component is initialized and rendered in what could be an invalid state. 

I am not seeing a way without using `ngOnInit` or `ngOnChanges` to get the desired behavior of responding to `input` signal changes and perform logic that must be run before children components are initialized.

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 17.3.1
Node: 18.17.0
Package Manager: pnpm 8.6.12
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: undefined
...

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.1703.1
@angular-devkit/core         17.3.1
@angular-devkit/schematics   17.3.1
@schematics/angular          17.3.1
```


### Anything else?
 
This may not be a "bug", but I'm not seeing any best practices, documentation, or discussions that show how to work-around this behavior change from using `ngOnChanges` to non-template based changes that need to occur before children components are initialized.

Issues.Title: Unit test fails for Pipes that use an effect and inject ChangeDetectorRef
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

We currently have a Unit Test that uses an `effect` and also injects the `ChangeDetectorRef`. Since we not only inject services and the `ChangeDetectorRef` we are want to mock away the services. Therefore we are using a `TestBed`. 

With this setup we always run into the following error:

```
TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading '2')
```

The error originates from the `effect.ts` - if (!cdr || !(cdr._lView[FLAGS] & LViewFlags.FirstLViewPass)) {, where the ChangeDetectorRef is being injected, but it gets the mock instead, so cdr._lView is undefined, which is not properly handled.

I already found this issue here which seems to be related: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/53796

In the mentioned issue they inject the `ChangeDetectorRef` inside a service which is not the place to use the change detector since its tied to the component concept. However I think it is valid to use the `ChangeDetectorRef` inside a pipe. In the end this is also what the `async` pipe does under the hood.

@pkozlowski-opensource mentioned that we should not mock framework internals for our own test. Generally I think this is a good thing, but I could also see how someone wants to ensure that some critical `markForCheck` is guaranteed to be there.  This could be easily achieved by mocking the `cdr` and writing a test that the method is called.

The second point here is that if you do not mock the `ChangeDetectorRef` your test will fail with the following error:

```
NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(DynamicTestModule)[DemoPipe -> ChangeDetectorRef -> ChangeDetectorRef]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for ChangeDetectorRef!
```

I created a small reproduction example which I pushed here: https://github.com/kreuzerk/effect-test-pipe

The error can be reproduced with the following steps:
- Checkout repo
- npm i
- npm run test

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/kreuzerk/effect-test-pipe

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
When mocking the `ChangeDetectorRef` you get this error:


TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading '2')
```

If you do not mock the `ChangeDetectorRef` you get this error
```
NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(DynamicTestModule)[DemoPipe -> ChangeDetectorRef -> ChangeDetectorRef]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for ChangeDetectorRef!```
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 17.3.3
Angular: 17.3.2
```


### Anything else?

### Description

A common mistake when using signals in templates, is to forget about calling the signal to get its value.

We already have protection against this in template interpolations. But we need the same kind of protection in regular bindings, for example:
```

```
or
```
<my-component [someInput]="'someString' + mySignal">I forgot to add parentheses</my-component>
```

I'm not very familiar with Angular internals but this seems like something that could be an "Extended diagnostic", like the template interpolation one?

Issues.Title: No way to access compilation output files
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Description

I have an esbuild plugin that is resposible to collect outputFiles after compilation (using `onEnd` hook with `result.outputFiles`).

When using application builder (esbuild) with custom plugins there is no way to access full list of outputFiles, only those emitted by `main` entrypoint compilation. There is no way to access additional files emited by angular builder, such as `polyfills`, assets, styles etc.

Previously, with using webpack plugin, i was able to get full list of outputFiles by using `processAssets` compilation hook.

I need to list emited files, as this is only way to get full names with filenames hash.

MY point is to build something like manifest of compilation result output files.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like to be able to access all compilation files by esbuild plugin.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

An alternative could be to access output files as an result of builder output, currently `build` command only returns `{success: true}` without information about output files.

The new-in-17.3 hideSingleSelectionIndicator and hideMultipleSelectionIndicator flags in MAT_BUTTON_TOGGLE_DEFAULT_OPTIONS are set in such a way that checkmarks will show up by default for all Material button toggles, regardless of M3 or otherwise. 1. Load up an existing app with mat-button-toggle.
2. Oops, default checkmarks!


### Expected Behavior

The checkmark should not be the default in a minor release.

Checkmarks all over the place.
